After all women do all virtually or in fact have an experience of the inside, an experience of the capacity for other, an experience of non-negative change brought about by the other, of positive receptivity (Cixous Reader, 135).

总而言之，《社交网络》清楚地说明了西苏和德里达之间的区别，他们都注重过程。德里达的方法是战术性的；他刻意避免特定的最终目标。然而，西苏更注重目标。这就是为什么她更加强调性欲，这种驱动力本质上是目标导向的。Facebook 旨在帮助哈佛大学的学生找到性伴侣；马克的所有成就，包括他的财富，都不足以安慰他没有女朋友。他被性欲所驱使。这就是这部电影的讽刺之处和希望之源。正如片尾的年轻女子向他指出的那样，他试图成为一个自我挫败的人，也就是说，没有女人会想要的那种人。唯一的希望，也是模糊的希望，是他或许认识到需要改变他的目标。影片开头“波士顿大学”的年轻女子埃丽卡为马克提供了关键。影片接近尾声时，马克试图和她说话，但她拒绝了，因为他不但没有道歉，反而试图继续他未竟的事业，而她显然不想要这些。但西苏斯明确指出，性欲、性欲望永远是有目标导向的，在这方面，女性扮演着特殊的角色，不仅要解构男性和他们的主要叙事，还要使他们社会化，帮助他们成为能与自我怀疑相兼容的人。这对马克来说难道不是一种进步吗？这难道不就是“他人带来的非负面变化、积极接受”的一个例子吗？

To conclude, “The Social Network” provides a clear illustration of the difference between Cixous and Derrida, both of whom focus upon process. Derrida’s method is tactical; he studiously avoids specific end goals. Cixous, however, is more goal-oriented. That is why she gives more emphasis to the libido, a drive that by its very nature is goal directed. Facebook is designed to help Harvard geeks find a sexual partner; all of Mark’s accomplishments, including his fortune, are not for him sufficient consolation for the lack of a girlfriend. He is driven by libido. That is the source of the irony of the film and of its hope. As the young woman at the end points out to him, he is trying to be something that is self-defeating, that is, the kind of person no woman will want. The only hope, and it is a vague one, is that he may recognize the need to change his goal. Erica, the young woman at “BU” at the beginning of the film, provides the key for Mark. Near the end he tries to speak to her, but she refuses because instead of apologizing he tries to take up where he left off, and she understandably wants none of it. But the point that Cixous makes clear is that the libido, the sexual appetite, is always goal-directed, and in that regard woman has a special role to play, not merely to deconstruct men and their master narratives, but also to socialize them, helping them to be self-doubting compatible human beings. Wouldn’t that be an improvement for Mark? Wouldn’t that be an example of “non-negative change brought about by the other, of positive receptivity”?

“毫无结论的结论”

“A conclusion in which nothing is concluded”

这个标题来自塞缪尔·约翰逊的《拉塞拉斯》（1759 年），这是我几年前写的第一本书的主题。那本书和这本书的目标并没有太大的不同。我的兴趣一直是解释的伦理本质。伦理通常被定义为对“美好生活”的追求。对我来说，伦理的核心源自前面提到的塔木德原则：“拯救一个人就是拯救整个世界。”解释与这个概念相关，因为它涉及从最深层意义上倾听对方；文学和所有艺术一样，是另一种艺术的表达。但解释性读者和文本之间随之而来的对话必须有目标，也就是说，我们需要关注的不是我们想听到什么，而是对方“想要表达什么”，即作者的目的。通过这种方式，文学解释与生活相关；如果我们不听他或她的话，从塔木德的伦理术语来看，我们不太可能拯救某人。这一原则在我们医学领域的生活最为突出。熟练的医生仔细而敏锐地检查了病人，并阅读了文本（通常是测试结果的形式），然后将主观和客观因素拼凑在一起，得出诊断。医学解释的艺术是一种涉及阅读和个人交流的道德行为，虽然我们不认为文学解释涉及生死攸关的问题，但有人可能会说，在伟大的悲剧中，尤其是《李尔王》，正是这样的问题处于危险之中。我写过很多关于这一解释过程的书：那些对我的观点细节感兴趣的人应该查阅参考书目。我在这里要承认的是，本研究中对理论或电影的每一个分析无疑都带有我对道德解释的偏爱。与其再次提出这种观点，冒着西苏所说的男性主宰形式的风险，我认为更有用的是思考为什么文学理论与商业成功的电影有关。在这方面，我效仿了约翰逊的例子。《拉塞拉斯》讲述了一个关于“人生选择”的故事——现代意义上的人生选择大致相当于职业选择——但正如最后一章的标题所暗示的那样，这个问题并没有得到解决。故事结尾的暗示是，在我看来，我们应该摒弃那些阻碍探索的人生选择，那些无意义或令人麻木的职业，因为约翰逊认为，寻求了解人生选择的知识比停留在自满的安全中更能让我们感到快乐。我希望让读者自己选择主理论，这是一个涵盖所有其他概念的概念，并建议读者，完全避免理论会减少我们对生活的理解和享受。

This title is from that of the last chapter of Samuel Johnson’s Rasselas (1759), which was the subject of my first book some years ago. The goals of that book and this one are not markedly different. My interest has remained the ethical nature of interpretation. Ethics is usually defined as the pursuit of the “good life.” The heart of ethics for me derives from the Talmudic principle previously cited: “He (or she) who saves one person saves the whole world.” Interpretation is related to this notion because it involves hearing in the deepest sense the other; literature, like all the arts, is an expression of another. But the conversation that ensues between the interpretive reader and the text must be goal-directed, that is, we need to attend, not to what we want to hear, but to what the other is “getting at,” the writer’s purpose. By this means literary interpretation is related to life; we are much less likely to save someone, in the ethical terms of the Talmud, if we do not listen to him or her. This principle is most prominent in our lives in the field of medicine. Having carefully and perceptively examined the patient and read the text, usually in the form of test results, the skillful doctor pieces together the subjective and the objective to arrive at a diagnosis. The art of medical interpretation is an ethical act involving reading and personal interchange, and although we do not think of literary interpretation as involving matters of life and death, one could argue that in the great tragedies, particularly King Lear, just such matters are at stake. I have written a number of books about this interpretive process: those interested in the details of my view should consult the bibliography. My point here is to confess that every analysis of a theory or a film in this study undoubtedly bears the stamp of my predilection for ethical interpretation. Instead of once again advancing that view, risking a form of what Cixous calls male mastery, I think it would be more useful to reflect on the question of why literary theory relates to commercially successful movies. In this respect, I am following Johnson’s example. Rasselas is a story about the quest for the “choice of life”—the modern rough equivalent would be a career choice—but, as the title of its last chapter suggests, no resolution to that question is found. The implication at the end of that narrative, as I read it, is that one should eliminate choices of life that impede the quest, mindless or mind-numbing careers, because Johnson believes that knowledge, seeking to learn about choices of life, makes us less unhappy than remaining in complacent security. I wish to leave the choice of a master-theory quest, a conception that envelops all of the others, open to the reader, with the suggestion that to avoid theory altogether is to lessen our understanding and enjoyment of life.

过去 25 年的电影与理论相关，因为这些想法丰富了电影艺术，即有助于卖座和激发思考，给人带来乐趣，也滋养心灵。为什么？理论家是颠覆者，不一定是政治意义上的颠覆者，而是他们表达质疑既定假设的创新思想。出于这个原因，本卷分析的所有理论家都使用解构主义，正如我们所见，这是一种解开公认真理的接缝的策略。但他们不是革命者；他们的写作太复杂和难以针对《邮差》中邮递员所说的“人民”。他们的兴趣在于表达新思想，这些新思想是针对专业研究领域的同事的。即使这些想法渗透到一般话语中，也只有少数人能清楚地理解它们，而许多人只是模糊地熟悉它们。“解构”一词是常用语，但很少以与德里达的表述相关的方式使用。伍迪·艾伦的《解构哈利​​》是本研究中唯一一个熟悉文学理论术语的电影制作人的例子，它使用解构的方式几乎不需要德里达的写作知识。而且，你会记得，我发现解构与艾伦的《人人都说我爱你》更相关，而不是《解构哈利​​》。

Movies of the past 25 years relate to theory because these ideas enrich the art of cinema, that is, help to sell seats and stimulate thought, giving pleasure and also nourishing the mind. Why? Theorists are subversives, not necessarily in the political sense, but in that they articulate innovative ideas that question established assumptions. For that reason, all the theorists analyzed in this volume use deconstruction, a strategy, as we have seen, for unraveling the seams of accepted truths. But they are not revolutionaries; their writing is far too complex and difficult to be directed at what the postman in “Il Postino” calls “il popolo,” the people. Their interest is in the articulation of new ideas, which are directed at their colleagues in specialized fields of study. Even when these ideas seep into general discourse, they are clearly understood by few and only vaguely familiar to many. The term “deconstruction” is in common parlance, but it is seldom used in a way related to the formulation by Derrida. Woody Allen’s “Deconstructing Harry,” the single instance in this study of a movie-maker showing familiarity with a term of literary theory, uses deconstruction in a way that requires little knowledge of Derrida’s writing. And, as you will recall, I found deconstruction more pertinent to Allen’s “Everyone Says I Love You” than to “Deconstructing Harry.”

我的观点不是理论以某种方式嵌入现代电影中；相反，理论帮助我们理解电影制作人如何实现他们的目的，电影有助于解释理论。当塔伦蒂诺描绘一个纳粹，他能够理解身为犹太人意味着什么，但又不会停止做纳粹时，解构主义得到了生动的体现，使我们能够理解这个角色。《贫民窟的百万富翁》通过了解控制贫民窟的权力结构，阐明了问答题的答案，体现了福柯的“权力-知识”概念。《单身男子》同时向我们展示了 20 世纪 60 年代和当今同性恋者的处境，从而阐明了读者对“期望视野”的反应概念。《朗读者》提出了一个关于潜意识作为语言的问题，拉康帮助解决了这个问题：一个看似正派的女人如何能忍受纳粹的过去 15 年，并且只有在学会阅读后才承担责任。《邮差》提出了一个关于公共领域和私人领域之间关系的马克思主义问题。詹姆逊的内在形式概念明确了邮递员对比阿特丽斯的爱与导致他死亡的更大的政治力量之间的关系。最后，西苏帮助我们理解了《达格纳姆制造》中的丽塔如何能够在没有威胁男人。因此，丽塔是西苏女权主义的一个很好的例子。理论的有趣创新有助于我们理解电影中哪些是新颖和有趣的，这些电影生动地体现了理论思想：电影和理论之间的互动是双向的，彼此相互影响。

My point is not that theory is somehow embedded in modern movies; rather, theory helps us understand how the film-makers achieve their ends and movies help explain theory. When Tarantino portrays a Nazi who can understand what it is to be a Jew without ceasing to be a Nazi, deconstruction is vividly exemplified and enables us to understand this character. Illustrating Foucault’s concept of “power-knowledge,” Slumdog learns the answers to the quiz questions by understanding the power structures that control the slum. “A Single Man” shows us simultaneously the situation of the homosexual in the 1960s and in the present day, thereby clarifying the reader response conception of “horizons of expectation.” “The Reader” poses a problem about the unconscious as language that Lacan helps resolve: how can a seemingly decent woman live with her Nazi past for 15 years and only after learning to read accept responsibility. “Il Postino” raises a Marxist question about the relationship between the public and the private domains. Jameson’s concept of inner form makes clear how the postman’s love for Beatrice is related to the larger political forces that result in his death. And finally, Cixous helps us understand how Rita, in “Made in Dagenham,” can bring about the reform of women’s rights without threatening men. Rita thus serves as a fine example of Cixous’s feminism. The interesting innovations of theory aid our understanding of what is new and entertaining in films that vividly exemplify the theoretical ideas: the interaction between film and theory works in both directions, each throwing light on the other.

然而，理论与电影之间的鸿沟仍然存在。（我解构了自己吗？）用博斯韦尔对约翰逊的一首诗的描述来说，理论家的著作“和希腊文一样难懂”。西苏斯称他们为“廉洁之人”，因为他们对普通读者毫不妥协。从定义上讲，本书收录的电影面向广大观众，但众所周知，腐败在电影界盛行。问题在于，流行艺术需要通过提出创新来吸引观众，但并不总是兑现承诺。约翰·德莱顿在他的讽刺诗《麦克弗莱克诺》（1678 年）中预见到了这个问题。标题指的是德莱顿的同时代人托马斯·沙德威尔，他是一位非常成功的喜剧剧作家。当时，喜剧和今天的电影一样受欢迎。德莱顿批评沙德威尔用新想法吸引观众，但最后却以老套的方式结束他的戏剧。德莱顿解释说，沙德威尔可以通过留下新的和令人不安的想法而赚更多的钱，“从不偏离常理”。观众离开剧院时会自满地为现状鼓掌。结果就是旧瓶装新酒，或者用我的学生的话来说，这是一种“好莱坞式的逃避”。

Nevertheless, the chasm between theory and film remains. (Have I deconstructed myself?) The writings of the theorists are, to use Boswell’s phrase for a Johnson poem, “as hard as Greek.” Cixous refers to them as the “incorruptibles” because they make no concession to the common reader. By definition, the films included in this volume are accessible to a broad audience, but corruption, as we all know, is rife in the film world. The problem is that the popular arts need to attract audiences by suggesting innovation, but do not always fulfill their promise. John Dryden anticipated this problem in his satirical poem, “MacFlecknoe” (1678). The title refers to Dryden’s contemporary, Thomas Shadwell, who was a very successful comic playwright. At the time, comedies were as popular as movies are today. Dryden takes Shadwell to task for tempting audiences with new ideas but then concluding his plays in the same old ways. Dryden explains that Shadwell can make more money by leaving new and disturbing ideas unresolved, “never deviating into sense.” Audiences leave the theater complacently applauding the status quo. The result is new wine in old bottles or, as my students put it, a “Hollywood cop-out.”

本卷分析的一些电影可能属于这一类。但正如引言中指出的那样，我的目的是展示理论如何通过电影来澄清，电影如何通过理论来澄清，而不是评判电影的艺术价值。电影评论领域的专家可能会像德莱顿对沙德威尔的批评一样，对它们提出合理的批评。然而，电影和理论都追求创新，无论是外表还是真实的东西。

Some of the films analyzed in this volume may well fall into this category. But, as is pointed out in the Introduction, my object has been to show how theory is clarified by film and film is clarified by theory, not to judge the artistic merit of the films. Experts in the field of cinema criticism may well advance a justified critique of them like Dryden’s of Shadwell. Nevertheless, film and theory share a search for innovation, whether that be mere appearance or the real thing.

正如“分析的电影”列表所示，文学理论涉及的电影范围非常广泛，这表明一些在 20 世纪 70 年代和 80 年代首次提出时被认为是博学而晦涩的理论，在最近几十年已成为“时代精神”的一部分。正如引言中指出的那样，我的学生告诉我，这些想法现在已成为他们“期望视野”的一部分。我们与子孙后代的对话将部分取决于对文学理论基本原理的理解。

The fact that literary theory pertains to a wide range of films, as is indicated by the list of “Films Analyzed,” suggests that some theories which when first formulated in the 1970s and 1980s were considered erudite and obscure have in the more recent decades become part of the “Zeitgeist,” the spirit of the age. My students have taught me, as was pointed out in the Introduction, how these ideas have now become a part of their “horizons of expectation.” Our conversations with our children and grandchildren will rest in part upon understanding the rudiments of literary theory.

第四章分析的《国王的演讲》获得了四项奥斯卡奖，分别是最佳影片奖、最佳男主角奖、最佳导演奖和最佳原创剧本奖。我们如何解释一部关于患有语言障碍的国王的电影在商业上取得成功并在专业上获得认可？人们对乔治六世作为历史人物的兴趣以及精彩的表演、导演和剧本不足以解释这一现象。这部电影中的想法肯定在其成功中发挥了一定作用。我们已经考虑过拉康的观点认为，个性是一种在话语中找到一席之地、找到我们的声音的功能。但现在，由于这部电影获得了好莱坞一家报纸所说的“同花顺”，它与这本书中的每一个想法都相关。

“The King’s Speech,” analyzed in Chapter Four, received four Academy Awards, for Best Picture, Best Actor, Best Director, and Best Original Screenplay. How do we explain the commercial success and professional recognition of a film about a king with a speech impediment? The interest in George VI as a historical figure and the wonderful acting, directing, and writing are not sufficient to explain this phenomenon. Surely the ideas in this movie must play a part in its success. We have already considered the Lacanian notion that personality is a function of finding a place in discourse, finding our voice. But now, since the film has gained what one Hollywood newspaper called “a royal flush,” it relates to every idea in this book.

《国王的演讲》解构了历史。乔治六世国王的统治被视为一个人与口吃的斗争，但丝毫不影响国王的个人尊严或历史意义。而且，国王从未完全控制口吃，这也是他如此受人喜爱和尊敬的原因之一。我们看到了君主的脆弱之处，权力的缝隙一直存在，只是不那么显眼。当伯蒂在应对专横的父亲和残忍模仿他口吃的兄弟时，体验到了权力知识，科林·费尔斯发现自己成为了一部席卷好莱坞的低成本英国电影的明星。伯蒂被认为是一个敏感而慈爱的父亲，深受孩子们的宠爱，费尔斯在奥斯卡颁奖典礼上以伯蒂应有的诙谐谦逊宣布，他担心自己的职业生涯已经达到顶峰。

“The King’s Speech” deconstructs history. The reign of King George VI is seen as a man’s struggle with a stutter without in the least detracting from the King’s personal dignity or historical significance. And mastery of the stutter is never wholly achieved, which is in part what makes him so endearing to and respected by us. We see the vulnerable element of the monarch, the seams of power that remain to the end present if less obtrusive. As Bertie experiences power-knowledge in coping with an overbearing father and a brother who cruelly mimics his stammer, Colin Firth finds himself as the star of a low-budget British film that has stormed Hollywood. Bertie is seen as a sensitive and loving father doted on by his children, and Firth announces at the Academy Award ceremony with the witty self-effacement worthy of Bertie that he fears his career has peaked.

电影和演员的吸引力在于读者的反应。乔治六世作为“人民之王”一举成名，他是二战期间英国的王室领袖，而科林·费斯在戏剧界也获得了同等地位，因为他能够出色地演绎喜剧和严肃角色，部分原因是他的戏剧技巧结合了悲伤的笑声和严肃的微笑。普通人的元素，我们自己的元素，总是存在的。即使是后马克思主义也与此相关。大卫打败了歌利亚；好莱坞向小人物低头。为什么？因为他们欣赏电影的内在形式和结构，演员、女演员、编剧和布景设计师如何共同塑造出一个有凝聚力和美丽的整体，一个没有性或暴力的动人场面。最后，费斯的伟大才华指向女权主义思想。去年，他因在《单身男子》中扮演同性恋而获得同样的奖项。毫无疑问，费斯的才华之一就是他的表演中既体现了男性的统治力，又体现了女性的飞翔。正如海伦娜·伯翰·卡特本人凭借这部电影获得奥斯卡奖提名时所说，当被问及她是否对没有获奖感到失望时，她说道：“但我的国王赢了。”毫无疑问，这些来自文学理论的思想一定有助于这部电影的艺术认可和成功。文学理论正在成为我们文化结构的一部分。

The appeal of the movie and the actor pertains to reader-response. George VI is catapulted to fame as the “people’s King,” the royal leader of Great Britain during World War II, and Colin Firth achieves equal status in the theatrical world for his ability to excel in both comic and serious roles in part because his theatrical technique combines both sad laughter and serious smiles. An element of the ordinary person, of ourselves, is always there. Even post-Marxism has relevance here. David defeats Goliath; Hollywood bows to the little guy. Why? Because they admire the inner form and structure of the movie, how the actors, actresses, writers, and set designers have together molded a cohesive and beautiful whole, a moving spectacle without sex or violence. Lastly, Firth’s great talent points to feminist ideas. The previous year he won the same award for playing a homosexual in “A Single Man.” Doubtless part of Firth’s talent is that male mastery and female flight are both manifested in his performance. As Helena Bonham Carter, herself nominated for an Academy Award for her part in the film, remarked when asked if she were disappointed not to have received the award, “But my king won.” Surely, these ideas from literary theory must have contributed to the artistic recognition and success of this film. Literary theory is becoming part of the fabric of our culture.

通常出现的最后一个问题是，这六种不同的理论如何结合在一起？我更愿意保留它们的差异。也许可以提供一些总体概念，将它们全部包括进来，就像一个漏水的大帐篷，但我不知道这种结构有多大用处。弗雷德里克·詹姆逊在这一点上很有说服力：

The final question that usually arises is how do these six different theories fit together? I prefer to leave them with their differences. Perhaps some overarching concept could be provided that would include them all rather like a large leaky tent, but I wonder how useful a structure it would be. Fredric Jameson is very persuasive on this point:

在伟大的哲学体系终结之后出现的理论，在某种市场环境下，往往会变成一整套不同的名牌。如果这样说似乎太轻率，那么我们可以说理论以有名无实的理论、特定的个人语言或私人语言的形式存在。哲学体系的全部意义在于吸收各种思想，并赋予它们一种单一的连贯的语言、概念性和术语集。从这个意义上说，哲学的终结意味着没有人认为连贯性是可能的。这意味着我们必须同时讲所有这些理论语言。真的没有办法将它们综合成一种主语言；甚至没有人想这样做（Jameson Reader，150-1）。

Theory emerging after the end of great philosophical systems, in a kind of market environment, has tended to become a whole set of different name brands. If that seems too frivolous to say, then we can say that theory exists as named theories, as specific idiolects or private languages. The whole point of the philosophical system is to take a mass of ideas in the air of all kinds and give them a single coherent language, conceptuality, and set of terms. In that sense, the end of philosophy means that no one thinks that coherence is possible any more. This means that we have to speak all these theoretical languages all at the same time. There really is no way to synthesize them into a master language; nor is there even a desire to do so (Jameson Reader, 150–1).

也许我们现在生活在一个折衷主义的时代，在这个时代，我们结合各种理论或语言（詹姆逊称之为）来解决具体问题。哲学，即一种包罗万象的理论，可能是历史上最后一个绝对的理论。我们坚持它，就像我们坚持民主是世界上所有民族的最佳制度一样，但信念越来越少。如果是这样，我希望有一种负责任或道德的折衷主义，一种致力于理解不同理论，以不完全矛盾和不一致的方式将它们结合起来的折衷主义。

Perhaps we now live in an age of eclecticism in which we combine various theories or languages, as Jameson calls them, to resolve concrete problems. Philosophy, that is, one all-encompassing theory, may be the last absolute to pass out of history. We cling to it, just as we do to the belief that democracy is the best system for all peoples of the world, with less and less conviction. If so, I hope for a responsible or ethical eclecticism, one that is dedicated to understanding the different theories, to combining them in ways that are not completely contradictory and inconsistent.

利用电影进行文学理论教学的建议

Suggestions for teaching literary theory by way of movies

介绍

Introduction

教授文学理论的第一步是让学生接触材料。大多数人一开始都会退缩，认为这超出了他们的理解范围。因此，我组织课程时要求每个学生就一位理论家和两位电影做口头报告。这些报告在课程开始时最多五分钟，旨在开始讨论。重点不是学生报告应该掌握或教导理论家。相反，他或她应该提出问题，指出困扰或感兴趣的段落。我的策略是让全班参与讨论：我从一开始就明确表示，如果你在别人做报告时不参与，你就不能指望那个人在你报告时帮助你，他们都参与其中，结果是他们理解的远比他们认为的要多。对于教师来说，学生之间最多 20 分钟的初步讨论的作用是让你发现对他们来说问题和争论点是什么。我把一周分成三节课，第一节讲理论家，接下来两节课各讲一部电影。在为期 15 周的课程中，有六位理论家，那么每位理论家有两周的课程。每两周的课程包括两节理论课和四节电影课。

The first step in teaching literary theory is getting the students to engage with the material. Most are at first put off, believing that it is all beyond them. So I organize the course with the requirement that each student does an oral report on one theorist and two on a film. Given at the beginning of class for a maximum of five minutes, these reports are designed to begin discussion. The point is not that the student reporting is supposed to master or teach the theorist. Instead, he or she should raise questions, pointing to passages that troubled or interested him or her. My strategy here is to engage the entire class in discussion: I make clear at the outset that if you do not participate when someone else is giving a report you cannot expect that person to come to your aid when you are reporting, They are all in it together, and the result is that they understand a good deal more than they believe they do. For the instructor, the function of this initial discussion among the students for a maximum of 20 minutes is that you discover what for them are the problems and the issues. I divide up the week into, say, three classes with the first on the theorist and the following two on one film each. In a 15-week term considering six theorists, you then have two weeks for each theorist. Each two-week period involves two sessions on theory and four classes on films.

电影提出了一个不同的问题。学生们把它们看作纯粹的娱乐，倾向于评判而不是分析它们。我强调，重点不在于你是否喜欢它们，或者你是否认为它们是好的或坏的。相反，目的是像解读文学作品一样解读它们。有些人试图将电影应用于理论，但我不鼓励这样做。我更希望他们分析电影本身，而将理论应用留给我。主要的困难是让他们相信商业上成功的电影是值得解读的。关于观看电影，我发现大多数教育机构都有一台中央计算机，它连接到所有学生的计算机。所有课堂上的影片可以复制到这个主机里，并设置密码保护版权，这样学生就可以随时观看。显然，你没有足够的时间在课堂上放映这些影片，而安排在课外放映这些影片，对于一些学生来说，不可避免地会与其他课程或课外活动发生冲突。

The films present a different problem. The students see them as mere entertainment and tend to judge rather than analyze them. I emphasize that the point is not whether you like them or not, or whether you believe they are good or bad. Rather, the object is to interpret them as you would a work of literature. Some try to apply the film to the theory, but I discourage that. My preference is that they analyze the movie in itself and leave the application to theory to me. The main difficulty is convincing them that commercially successful movies can be worthy of interpretation. With regard to viewing the films, I have found that most educational institutions have a central computer that links to all of the student computers. All the films of the class can be copied into this mainframe, with a password to protect copyright, so that the students may watch the films whenever they wish. Obviously, you do not have enough time to show them in class, and trying to arrange for showing them outside of class inevitably involves for some students conflicts with their other classes or extracurricular activities.

报告和学生讨论（同样是 20 分钟）结束后，我开始提问，特别是那些之前没有发言的学生。鉴于电影可以在线观看，理论作业不超过 30 页，所以没有理由不在课堂上做好准备。我要强调的是，作业必须在课前完成，学生在阅读或观看电影后将被要求参与。我将评论限制在最后 15-20 分钟，试图形成一个与学生在讨论中提出的观点相关并融入其中的立场。

Once the reports and student discussions—again, 20 minutes—are concluded, I then begin by asking questions, particularly of those who have not spoken earlier. Given that the films are available online and that theory assignments are no more than 30 pages in length, there can be no excuse for not being prepared in class. And I would emphasize that the assignments are to be completed before class begins, and that the students will be expected to participate, having done the reading or seen the film. I restrict my comments to the last 15–20 minutes, trying to formulate a position that relates to and incorporates points made by the students in discussion.

本课程要求学生提交三份口头报告、两篇论文（一篇短文和一篇长文）以及期末考试。短文应在学期第四周提交，包括对一篇理论论文进行三到五页的分析，论文交还给学生后，学生将在课堂上进行分析。我会与每位学生讨论短文，并为他们制定长文的单独主题，长文应在学期第十二周提交。长文涉及一件他们特别感兴趣的艺术、文学、电影或任何造型艺术作品。他们的任务是在图书馆里找到两篇将两种不同理论应用于该作品的批判性论文，并评估这些论文对更好地理解艺术作品的效用。这里的目的是强调理论的实际效用和使用多种理论的能力，因为大多数学生都会发现这两种理论都有用。这篇论文的最终目标是向他们展示理论的一般性，即通过结合和修改过去的理论来进行。期末考试会用到学生们在学期中提出的一个问题：那些被应用于一个理论的电影是否可以应用于另一个理论？答案是肯定的，而这也是我要求他们在期末考试中写的内容，即分析两部电影来阐述不同于课堂上所用到的理论。有些老师太不要脸了。

The requirements for the course are three oral reports, two papers, one short and one long, and a final exam. The short paper is due during the fourth week of term and involves a three-to-five-page analysis of one theory essay to be taken up in class after the papers are handed back to the students. I have a conference with each student about the short paper and plan with them an individual topic for the long paper, which is due during the 12th week of term. The long paper involves a work of art, literature, film, or any plastic art that is of particular interest for them. Their assignment is to find in the library two critical essays that apply two different theories to this work and to assess the utility of these essays toward better understanding of the work of art. The object here is to emphasize the practical utility of theory and the ability to use more than one theory, since most of the students will find some use from both theories. The ultimate goal of the paper is to show them that theory proceeds generically, that is, by combining and modifying past theories. The final exam uses a question that the students raise during the semester: can the films that have been applied to one theory be applied to another? Yes indeed, and that is what I ask them to write about on the final, namely, to analyze two films to illustrate theories other than those that these films were used to exemplify in class. Some teachers are shameless.

第一章：解构

Chapter One: Deconstruction

德里达在很多方面都是本书收录的理论家中最难理解的。我的学生发现他的作品常常令人沮丧，难以理解。作为介绍，我建议学生观看关于德里达的纪录片《德里达》（2002 年），由柯比·迪克和艾米·齐林·科夫曼执导，雅克·德里达和玛格丽特·德里达。这部电影让德里达显得人性化，并包含足够的传记信息以满足他们对历史细节的好奇心。虽然这部电影对理解德里达的思想帮助不大，但它确实阐明了德里达的重要见解是什么，以及德里达如何与他所受教育的哲学传统区分开来。

Derrida is in many ways the most difficult of the theorists included in this volume. My students have found his writings often frustrating and hard to follow. As an introduction, I suggest that the students watch the documentary film about Derrida, entitled “Derrida,” (2002), directed by Kirby Dick and Amy Ziering Kofman, starring Jacques Derrida and Marguerite Derrida. This movie gives a human face to Derrida and includes enough biographical information to satisfy their curiosity for historical detail. Although of little help in understanding Derrida’s ideas, the movie does make clear what are the important insights and how Derrida is to be distinguished from the philosophical tradition in which he was schooled.

至于阅读作业，我建议阅读短篇，两三篇，每篇不超过 20 页。为了让学生做好阅读准备，我强调没有人会觉得阅读很容易，并鼓励学生阅读练习的要点，不要因为不理解某个特定术语或典故而停下来。在学生阅读材料之前向他们解释你感兴趣的概念是什么是有帮助的，但不要规定接下来的讨论结果。

With regard to reading assignments, I would suggest short pieces, two or three of no more than 20 pages each. To prepare the students for the reading I stress that no one finds them easy, and encourage the students to read for the gist of the exercise and not to stop because they do not understand a specific term or allusion. It is helpful to explain to students before they read the material what are the concepts you are interested in pursuing but without dictating the outcome of the discussion that will follow.

我每周有一节课讲写作，两节课讲典型电影。你也可以选择一起学习。无论你如何组织课程，我都会强调学生要以自己的方式看待电影，而不是只考虑理论：你喜欢或不喜欢这部电影的什么地方，你认为它的意义或艺术目标是什么？许多学生都渴望知道你将如何利用电影来阐述理论。我告诉他们把这项工作留给我。我需要工作。根据我的经验，如果学生以自己的方式分析电影，他们更有可能参与到问题中来。然后，你就可以从电影转向理论；此外，你还可以清楚地表明，电影和理论之间的桥梁需要超越描述和主题，转向解释。因此，我建议在讨论或讲座之后布置我的章节。这样，学生就会明白，考虑这些理论家的议程并不是固定的，无论是我还是其他人。此外，这一程序所导致的分析很可能导致我对电影的解读和理论家的立场产生质疑。

I devote one class a week to the writings and two a week to exemplary films. You may prefer to study them together. However you organize the course, I would stress that the students approach the movies in their own terms quite apart from theory: what do you like or dislike about the film, what do you think is its point or artistic goal? Many students are eager to anticipate how you will use the movies to illustrate a theory. I tell them to leave that chore to me. I need the work. The students are, in my experience, more likely to become engaged with the issues if they analyze the films as films in their own terms. Then you can move on the interpretive level from the films to theory; moreover, you will thus be able to make clear that the bridge between film and theory requires moving beyond description and thematics to interpretation. For this reason, I would suggest that my chapters be assigned after your discussion or lecture. In this way, the students will come to understand that the agenda for consideration of these theorists is not fixed, whether by me or anyone else. Also, this procedure can result in analysis that may well lead to questioning my interpretations of the films and the positions of the theorists.

尤其是关于德里达，我会简要介绍两个或最多三个思想：对我来说，选择是去中心化和起源神话，但也可以选择许多其他可能性，例如“延异”和“踪迹”。指出阅读材料中将成为课堂分析重点的特定段落，并强调学生报告应特别关注这些段落，也是一个好主意。最后，如果班上有不到 30 名学生，我会提醒他们，每个人都会被要求谈论作业，即使只是解释他们不理解的内容以及他们最初在哪里迷失。这项练习的作用是向他们表明，他们既不孤单，也不是特别笨拙，他们的同学和大多数老师都有同样的问题。一旦你向他们展示了问题段落不是随机的，而是我们大多数人共有的，你就找到了讨论和分析的焦点。

With regard to Derrida in particular, I would give a brief introduction to two or at most three ideas: for me, the choice would be on decentering and originary myths, but many other possibilities could be chosen, such as “différance” and “trace.” It is also a good idea to point to particular passages in the readings that will be the focus of analysis in class and to stress that student reports should pay special attention to them. Finally, if the class has less than 30 students I warn them that each will be asked to speak about the assignment, even if only to explain what they do not understand and where they first became lost. The function of this exercise is to show them that they are neither alone nor particularly dense, and that their fellow students and most teachers had the same problems. Once you show them that the problem passages are not random but shared by most of us, you have located focal points for discussion and analysis.

正如我在引言中提到的，一开始最大的障碍是让入门学生相信理论不仅仅适用于某些更高层次的生物，他们用别人听不懂的语言说话。相反，它是关于我们在阅读文本（文学或理论）时遇到的问题，以及帮助我​​们解决这些问题的概念。当然，这种理论概念是基于引言中考虑的前提，即理论不是哲学的一个分支，而是致力于在更高的普遍性层面上解决实践批评的问题。

As I suggested in the Introduction, the biggest obstacle in the beginning is convincing introductory students that theory is not merely for some higher order of beings who speak in a language no one else understands. Rather, it is about the sort of problems we confront in reading texts, literary or theoretical, and the concepts that help us resolve these problems. Of course, this conception of theory is based upon the premise, considered in the Introduction, that theory is not a branch of philosophy but devoted to solving the problems of practical criticism at a higher level of generality.

让学生对阅读作业中的概念有一个实用的理解是非常重要的。为了解释去中心化和起源神话，我有时会要求学生提供其他课程中的例子，在这些课程中，对文本的实际批评导致对未经审查的假设提出质疑。或者，我使用时事。在最近的银行业危机期间，我指出，美国最保守的总统之一已经将美国银行国有化，这一立场超越了极左翼人士，更不用说右翼人士了。因此，左翼和右翼之间的二元论被去中心化，而起源神话，即将自由企业国有化是严格的马克思主义决定，被理解为一个神话。

Giving the students a working understanding of the concepts in the reading assignment is very important. To explain decentering and originary myths I have on occasion asked students to provide examples from their other classes where practical criticism of texts has led to questioning unexamined assumptions. Alternatively, I use current events. During the recent banking crisis, I pointed out that one of the most conservative presidents of the United States had nationalized American banks, a position beyond that of those on the far left, let alone the right. Thus a binarism between left and right is decentered and an originary myth, the nationalizing of free enterprises as a strictly Marxist decision, is understood to be a myth.

一旦学生们开始理解解构主义是一种可以应用于任何人类创造物（特别是文学和思想）的过程，他们就会理解其他理论家如何使用解构主义来质疑既定立场并寻找创新的“缝隙”，正如德里达在电影“德里达”结尾处所说的那样，他想听到哲学家们回避的生活中哪些元素，比如他们的性生活，因为这会导致他们思想上的裂痕，为理论带来新的可能性。

Once the students begin to understand that deconstruction is a procedure that can be applied to any human creation, particularly literature and ideas, they will grasp how other theorists use deconstruction to call into question established positions and to find the “seams” for innovation, As Derrida says near the end of the film “Derrida,” he would like to hear about the elements of the lives of philosophers that they avoid, such as their sex lives, because that leads to fissures in their thoughts, new possibilities for theory.

我在专门讨论理论家写作的课程中强调，对关键思想有一个模糊的理解就足够了。在专门讨论电影的课程中，学生的概念会变得更加清晰，因为他们有具体的例子来帮助他们巩固自己的见解。提醒学生，你并不是在暗示作家和电影制作人比他们更熟悉理论：电影和理论之间的联系是你的一种教学和解释行为，而不是历史或传记陈述。

I stress during the sessions devoted to the theorist’s writing that a vague understanding of the key ideas is sufficient. During the sessions devoted to the films, student conceptions will sharpen as they have specific examples to help ground their insights. Remind the students you are not suggesting that the writers and movie-makers have any more familiarity with theory than they do: the connection between the films and theory is a pedagogical and interpretative move on your part, not a historical or biographical statement.

根据班级规模，我为每个理论家使用不超过两三部电影。大多数学生对电影比对书面作品更熟悉，但当我敦促他们将电影提升到解释性的水平时，我总是遇到阻力。许多人认为，商业上成功的电影仅仅是为了这个目的而写的，寻求某种更高的艺术目的是徒劳的。从某种意义上说，这符合你的目标，因为它使你能够强调你是将电影与德里达联系起来的解释的来源。但你可能需要警告他们，整个解释问题及其所包含的内容将成为第三章中解释学家讨论的主题。在这个阶段，我强调两点：1）解释服务于这门课的目的，即用电影来说明思想。所有的解释都有目的或目标；2）阐释致力于理解他人（这里指电影制作人）的目的。通过这种方式，我希望将电影的“使用”与“剥削”区分开来，剥削是指无视电影本身的内在艺术目的。

I use no more than two or three movies for each theorist, depending on the size of the class. Most students are much more at ease with the movies than with the written work, but I have always encountered resistance when urging them to the interpretive level with films. Many assume that commercially successful movies are written solely for that purpose and that the search for some higher artistic purpose is futile. In some sense that serves your goal, since it enables you to stress that you are the source of the interpretation that relates the film to, in this instance, Derrida. But you may want to warn them that the entire issue of interpretation and what it entails will be a topic taken up by the hermeneuticists in Chapter Three. At this stage I stress two points: 1) interpretation serves the purpose of this class, using movies to illustrate ideas. All interpretations have a purpose or goal; 2) interpretation is dedicated to understanding the goals of others, in this instance, the film-makers. By this means, I hope the “use” of films is to be distinguished from “exploitation,” that is, disregard of the intrinsic artistic purpose of the film in its own right.

最后，我发现，与历史描述或主题相反，解释的构成是什么，这一问题正是这门课程的潜台词。我的大多数学生都是由形式主义者训练出来的，他们对理论不感兴趣。历史描述或主题本身就是目的。我发现自己不断地引导学生超越这些见解，问他们为什么要看电影，为什么要读这本书。简而言之，理解理论用途的先决条件是定义解释的性质。然后，理论就可以被视为解决解释问题的方法。

Finally, I have found that the entire question of what constitutes interpretation as opposed to historical description or thematics is the subtext of the course. Most of my students had been trained by formalists who had no interest in theory. Historical descriptions or themes were ends in themselves. I found myself constantly driving the students beyond these insights, asking why see the movie, why read the book. In short, a prerequisite to understanding the use of theory is defining the nature of interpretation. Theory can then be seen to address the problems of interpretation.

第二章 米歇尔·福柯与“权力—知识”

Chapter Two: Michel Foucault and “power-knowledge”

我开始讨论福柯时首先要考虑话语的概念，因为在我看来，这是他最重要的两个见解“作者功能”和“权力知识”的基础。话语应该被理解为每一种交流形式，从早餐同伴的咕哝声和呻吟声到广告牌和短信，从涂鸦到小说，从火车汽笛声到交响乐，从色情杂志到博物馆图片。我们没有意识到我们生活的这个元素，因为我们沉浸其中：我们每天都在其中游泳。此外，我们习惯性地改变笔触，也就是说，随着每个新情况改变我们的话语。例如，我们在教室里的谈话与聚会上朋友之间的谈话非常不同。不同的说话方式与福柯所说的纪律有关：我们被纪律的规则和惯例所灌输，以至于我们忘记了违反它们会受到惩罚。如果您告诉教授而不是室友，您没有完成阅读作业，因为您更喜欢去滑雪，那么您的成绩将受到惩罚。

I begin the discussion of Foucault with a consideration of the notion of discourse, since it is the basis of what for me are his two most important insights, “author-function” and “power-knowledge.” Discourse should be understood as every form of communication, from the grunts and groans of breakfast companions to billboards and text messages, from graffiti to novels, from train whistles to symphonies, from porn magazines to museum pictures. We are unaware of this element of our life because we are immersed in it: we swim in it every day. Moreover we change strokes habitually, that is, alter our discourse with each new situation. Our conversation, for instance, in the classroom is very different from that among friends at a party. The different ways of speaking have to do with what Foucault calls disciplines: we are so imbued with the rules and conventions of disciplines that we forget that violations of them involve punishment. If you tell your professor as opposed to your roommate that you did not do the reading assignment because you preferred to go skiing you will be punished in terms of your grade.

“作者功能”是话语学科的结果。继续上面的例子，你可以对你的教授说，你很抱歉没能完成作业，但希望有机会弥补。现在，你不用撒谎，就巧妙地进入了“学生功能”，这更有可能将惩罚降到最低。达到“作者功能”地位的作者不必失去个人诚信或经历“身份危机”。他或她就像任何一位像样的游泳者一样，熟悉媒介或话语惯例的人，会对水流和波浪做出反应，这些力量超出了个人的控制范围。我们所有人都在日常生活中如此频繁地对这些力量做出反应我们只是潜意识地意识到它们。完全意识到它们就产生了福柯所说的“权力知识”。

“Author-function” is the result of the disciplines of discourse. To continue with the above example, you may say to your professor that you are sorry that you could not complete the assignment but would welcome the opportunity to make it up. Now, without telling a lie, you have moved deftly into your “student-function” which is much more likely to minimize a penalty. An author who achieves the stature of “author-function” need not lose personal integrity or have an “identity crisis.” He or she, like any decent swimmer, one familiar with the conventions of the medium or discourse, responds to the currents and waves, the powers beyond individual control. We all respond to these kinds of forces so regularly in our daily existence that we are only subliminally aware of them. Full awareness results in what Foucault calls “power-knowledge.”

“权力-知识”的概念不仅涉及权力作为话语中的纪律力量，还涉及另一个关键因素，即知识的限制，这是福柯的主要见解。继续以学生和教授为例，假设学生在完成作业后提出了一种解释，当被要求提供其意见的证据时，学生回答说：“这是我的解释，不需要进一步证明。我们所有的观点都是主观的，每个人都有权表达自己的意见。”学生将再次受到低分惩罚，即使他或她的观点如果经过适当记录，可能是聪明和创新的。通过违反话语学科的规则，这里是文学批评，学生的观点被驳回，不是被视为错误或不正确，而是被视为不属于知识领域，不是“在真实之内”，不被接纳为知识俱乐部、兄弟会或姐妹会。而且，我要强调的是，最伟大、最具创新性的想法往往质疑学科规则，质疑“权力知识”的力量，福柯本人和本书中所有其他理论家的情况就是如此。例如，德里达仍然被一些哲学家视为不写哲学的人。

The concept of “power-knowledge” involves not only power as the force of discipline in discourse but one other crucial factor, the limiting of knowledge, Foucault’s major insight. To continue with the example of the student and professor, suppose the student after making up the assignment offers an interpretation and, when asked for evidence of his or her opinion, replies, “That is my interpretation and it needs no further justification. All of our views are subjective and everyone has a right to their opinion.” The student will again be punished with a low grade, even though his or her opinion may, if properly documented, be intelligent and innovative. By violating the rules of the discipline of the discourse, here of literary criticism, the student’s views are dismissed, not considered as false or incorrect, but as not within the realm of knowledge, not “within the true,” not admitted to the club, fraternity or sorority of knowledge. And, I stress, the greatest and most innovative ideas often question the rules of the discipline, the power of “power-knowledge,” as is the case with Foucault himself and all the other theorists in this volume. Derrida, for instance, is still dismissed by some philosophers as someone not writing philosophy.

这一见解的含义广泛而多样。一旦学生掌握了它——哪里比学生更能体现“权力知识”呢？——他们就会开始带着它到处走。这些电影提供了有用的控制范围，因为一开始学生会把“权力知识”的概念与教条主义和我所说的“暴君教师”联系起来。但这些电影表明，“作者功能”和“权力知识”适用于除了这些滥用教学法的情况之外的情况。它们适用于希望向他人传授或允许思想自由的自由思想家。这就是为什么福柯在生命的尽头断言，他致力于的不是权力研究，而是伦理学，研究人们如何帮助自己和他人与权力谈判以实现自我表达。这时，我让学生们去看电影，并提出以下建议：与电影进行真正的对话。电影是一种自我表达的形式；试着让你的解读与你认为的电影的要点相一致。

The implications of this insight are vast and various. Once the students grasp it—and where is “power-knowledge” more manifest than for students?—they will start to go everywhere with it. The films provide useful perimeters of control because at first students associate the notion of “power-knowledge” with dogmatism and what I call “tyrant-teachers.” But the films show that “author-function” and “power-knowledge” apply in situations apart from these abuses of pedagogy. They apply to free thinkers who wish to impart or permit freedom of thought to others. That is why Foucault asserted near the end of his life that he had devoted himself, not to a study of power, but to ethics, how people could help themselves as well as others to negotiate with power to achieve self-expression. At this point I send the students off to watch the films with this advice: have a genuine conversation with the films. Cinema is a form of self-expression; try to see that your interpretation comes to terms with what you believe to be the point of the film.

一旦我们开始看电影，任务就变得容易多了，因为学生们自然而然地认同了主角，他们都是学生，在某种程度上，他们被置于需要学习才能生存或实现目标的环境中。话语和纪律的概念都是根据主角希望实现的目标来定义的。而这种成就以道德为标志，与成就腐败的“陪衬人物”不同，比如威塞克斯勋爵与莎士比亚、萨利姆与贾马尔、大卫与珍妮、黑天鹅与白天鹅、丹尼尔与马克。对福柯来说，适当的自我表达总是合乎道德的，因为它不仅涉及与权力的谈判同时也获取了可以帮助他人实现同样目标的知识，并开启了探索新类型和新形式的自我的讨论。

Once we get to the films, the task is much easier because the students naturally identify with the main characters who are all, in one way or another, students in that they are placed in environments where survival or achievement of their goals requires learning. The concepts of discourse and discipline are all defined in terms of what the protagonists wish to achieve. And that achievement is marked by an ethical end that is distinguished from “foil figures” whose achievements are corrupt, like that of Lord Wessex versus Shakespeare, Salim as opposed to Jamal, David and Jenny, the Black Swan and the White Swan, and Daniel and Mark. Proper self-expression for Foucault is always ethical, for it involves not only negotiating with power but also acquiring knowledge that helps others achieve the same end and opens the discourse to new kinds and forms of selfhood.

为了解释福柯的自我伦理概念，我以舞蹈为例，这种舞蹈在《黑天鹅》和《贫民窟的百万富翁》的结尾中明显存在，但在其他电影中却隐含其中。当妮娜在片刻间变成黑天鹅时，她终于体验到了自我满足，最后贫民窟的百万富翁和拉蒂卡在站台上跳舞庆祝他们的爱情。妮娜的舞蹈所涉及的纪律显而易见，但贫民窟的百万富翁和拉蒂卡的舞蹈是经过精心编排的，必须与其他人一起跳舞，这有点像芭蕾舞团。这三个人通过与他人共舞来实现自我表达，而且无论从字面上还是比喻上来说，都不会踩到其他舞者的脚趾。自我作为社交网络的一部分而显现出来，社交网络限制了它的运动，但允许个体在世界上实现，即被他人看到和听到。从这个意义上说，自我是通过传递他人的自我而传递的。对于福柯来说，这样的过程促进了新的自我：拉蒂卡是一名妓女，一个社会弃儿，然后她又成为一名在火车站台上公开庆祝婚礼的新娘。

To explain Foucault’s concept of the ethics of the self, I use the example of the dance, overtly present in “Black Swan” and the conclusion of “Slumdog Millionaire” but implicit in the other films. Nina finally experiences self-fulfillment when she becomes for a moment the black swan, and at the end Slumdog and Latika dance on the station platform in celebration of their love. The discipline involved in Nina’s dance is painfully obvious, but Slumdog and Latika are carefully choreographed and must dance in unison with the others, a sort of equivalent of the corps de ballet. These three people achieve self-expression by dancing with others and never, literally or figuratively, treading on the toes of the other dancers. The self becomes manifest as part of a social network, which constricts its movement but permits individuation to be realized in the world, that is, to be seen and heard by others. In that sense, the self is forwarded by forwarding the selfhood of others. And for Foucault such a procedure promotes new kinds of selfhood: Latika is a prostitute, an outcast of society, and then she is a bride celebrating her marriage in public on the railway platform.

第三章 接受理论：沃尔夫冈·伊瑟尔

Chapter Three: Reception theory: Wolfgang Iser

通常，解释一下伊瑟尔和姚斯是德国康斯坦茨大学的同事，这一理论源自康德和黑格尔的德国形而上学传统，这仅是两个最重要的来源，这很有帮助。学生们喜欢接受理论，因为它不像前两种理论那样抽象，而且为他们开辟了新的可能性。但这一理论容易受到两种滥用：1) 任何事情都可能发生，所有解释都具有同等价值；2) 最终结果是意识到解释的前提，这是一种自我意识。关于第一个，需要强调的是，文本限制了解释，空白和空白是由艺术作品造成的，而不仅仅是回应者造成的。从最深层意义上讲，阅读是关注艺术作品的差异性，进而关注另一个人，这是这一理论的核心。事实上，当学生问为什么伊瑟尔只局限于文学，而不对艺术进行概括时，我的回答是文学是艺术差异性最严格的形式；误读可以通过经验证明。此外，还原性阅读、非解释性阅读或最低限度解释性的阅读也显而易见。文学显然要求仔细关注文本，但又要求我们超越文本，或者通过解释来填补空白。

It is usually helpful to explain that Iser and Jauss were colleagues at the University of Constanz in Germany and that this theory is derived from the German metaphysical tradition of Kant and Hegel, to mention only the two most important sources. Students enjoy reception theory because it is less abstract then the previous two theories and opens up new possibilities for them. But it is a theory vulnerable to two abuses: 1) anything goes, all interpretations are of equal value; 2) the end result is awareness of the premises of interpretation, a form of self consciousness. With regard to the first, it needs to be emphasized that the text limits interpretation and that the gaps and blanks are created by the work of art and not solely by the responder. Reading, in the deepest sense, attending to the otherness of a work of art and, by extension, to another person, is at the heart of this theory. In fact when students ask why does Iser limit himself to literature and not generalize about art, I answer that literature is the most exacting form of artistic otherness; misreadings can be empirically demonstrated. Also, reductive readings, non-interpretive or minimally interpretive readings are immediately apparent. Literature overtly demands careful attention to the text and yet requires that we go beyond the text, or fill in the gaps, by way of interpretation.

关于第二个问题，即自我意识的自我反思，我强调这种观点在接受的早期阶段就存在了理论，这就是为什么我引用的大部分内容都是伊瑟尔的后期作品，从 20 世纪 80 年代开始，他开始发展他的批评作为一种人类学形式。自我反思的批评在文化背景下应用时会变得更加富有成效和有趣，当然，这也是 Jauss 的“期望视野”概念脱颖而出的地方，在这里，我们可以看到我们这个时代的文化假设与艺术作品时代的文化假设之间的相互作用。

With regard to the second problem, self-conscious navel-gazing, I emphasize that such a view was present in the early stages of reception theory and that is why most of my citations are from the later work of Iser, from the 1980s onward, when he began to develop his notion of criticism as a form of anthropology. Self-reflective criticism becomes much more fruitful and interesting when applied in a cultural context, and that of course is where Jauss’s concept of “horizons of expectation” comes to the fore, where we see the interplay between the cultural assumptions of our time and those of the age of the work of art.

我发现，我的大多数学生都对历史着迷，但对历史知之甚少。因此，值得澄清的是，现在大多数历史学家都承认历史写作是过去和现在的混合体。现在几乎没有人相信历史是一门社会科学，能够具有客观性。因此，姚斯的历史批评模型就是历史本身的模型。两者都具有内在的道德维度，即选择或挑选重要事物的原因：对于批评家来说，哪些视野是重要的以及为什么重要。

At this point I find that most of my students are fascinated by history but know little about it. It is therefore worth making clear that most historians now accept that historical writing is a mixture of past and present. Almost no one now believes that history is a social science, capable of objectivity. Hence, Jauss’s model for historical criticism is a model of history itself. Both have a built-in ethical dimension, namely, the reasons for choosing or selecting what is important: for the critic, what horizons are important and why.

现在你面对的是目的论问题：关注艺术的最终目标以及学生解释艺术的尝试。众所周知，大多数学生都没有发挥出全部潜力。因此，我发现在课堂上分析他们的论文的最终目标是有帮助的。因为他们很少走得足够远，通过询问或更好的做法是鼓励其他学生问“那又怎样，我为什么要关心？”，很容易推动他们走得更远，这种练习向他们表明，他们没有达到目的或最终目标，无论是他们自己的还是艺术作品的。但是，尽管他们对我坚持不懈的“那又怎样”问题有些恼火，他们还是可以到达那里，并发现描述只有在达到意向性时才会成为解释。

Now you confront the problem of teleology: attending to the final goals of art and of the students’ attempts to explain art. As we all know, most students are not pushed to their full potential. I, therefore, find that in-class analysis of the final goals of their papers is helpful. For they seldom go far enough, and it is easy to push them further by asking, or better yet, encouraging the other students to ask, “So what, why should I care?”, an exercise that shows them they are not getting to the telos or final goal, whether theirs or that of the work of art. But with some exasperation at my insistent “so what” questions, they can get there and discover that description only becomes interpretation when it arrives at intentionality.

任何一部电影都适合做这个练习。为什么《达芬奇密码》以裴氏金字塔的双 V 结尾？好学生回答说，因为上帝并不局限于一种性别。那又怎么样？我们为什么要关心上帝是不是男性沙文主义者？一位深思熟虑的学生回答说，因为另一种选择就是让女性承担比男性更多的原罪。这对女性来说太糟糕了，但对男性来说却是一件好事。但我们因此失去了女性对男性智力的批评，对男性主宰的微笑。啊，好吧，也许这就是为什么在结尾处苏菲甜甜地对罗伯特微笑，说“我不能走在水上”的原因吧？

Any of the films will serve well for this exercise. Why does the “The Da Vinci Code” end with the double V in the Pei pyramid? Because God is not limited to one gender, good students respond. So what? Why should we care whether or not God is a male chauvinist? Because the alternative is to burden women with more original sin than men, responds a thoughtful student. Too bad for women, but a good deal for men. But we are thereby deprived of the element of the female critique of male intelligence, the smile at male mastery. Ah, well, is that perhaps why near the end Sophie smiles sweetly at Robert, saying “I can’t walk on water”?

寻找目的或意向性涉及对结论的解释，包括理论家、电影和学生对两者的分析。大多数学生认为结论是尾声，是像狗尾巴一样被添加的片段。所以他们需要学会关注最终目标。《贫民窟的百万富翁》在这方面也做得很好。站台上的宝莱坞舞蹈似乎就是这样：宝莱坞、好莱坞的喧嚣。但事实就是这样吗？为什么有这么多人在跳舞，而不是只有两个恋人？为什么他们都跳同样的舞？为什么其他人都在庆祝《贫民窟的百万富翁》的胜利？亲人的死亡和幸存者身上的伤疤又是怎么回事呢？

The search for telos or intentionality involves an explanation of conclusions, that of the theorists, the films and the students’ analyses of both. Most students see conclusions as codas, bits tacked on like the tails of dogs. So they need to learn to focus on final goals. “Slumdog Millionaire” also works well in this regard. The Bollywood dance on the station platform seems to be just that: Bollywood, Hollywood hoopla. But is it just that? Why so many people dancing instead of just the two lovers? Why do they all do the same dance? Why are the others celebrating Slumdog’s victory? And what about the deaths of loved ones and the scars on the survivors?

第四章：雅克·拉康与后弗洛伊德主义

Chapter Four: Jacques Lacan and post-Freudianism

最优秀的学生意识到拉康的作品很难理解，不仅因为这些思想，还因为目标受众似乎是一种小团体或小圈子。为了解释这个“加密”过程，用德里达的术语来说，我指出，在质疑正统的弗洛伊德主义者时，拉康不仅提出了新的概念，而且威胁到了精神分析从业者的生计，而精神分析这一领域即使在 20 世纪中叶也带来了丰厚的经济回报和巨大的声望，尤其是在欧洲。因此，拉康被视为一个巨大的威胁，他用一种神秘的语言与他的追随者们隔绝。简而言之，他威胁到了他同行的生计。此外，我们读到的拉康的大部分作品最初并不是打算出版的，而是从研讨会笔记中整理出来的，目的是帮助他的追随者和学生。

The best students realize that Lacan’s writings are difficult, not only because of the ideas, but also because the intended audience seems to be a sort of in-group or coterie. To explain this “encrypting” process, to use a Derridean term, I point out that in questioning orthodox Freudians, Lacan is not merely presenting new conceptions but threatening the very livelihood of practicing psychoanalysts, a field that even in the mid-20th century brought rich financial rewards and great prestige, particularly in Europe. So Lacan was seen as a great threat and cocooned himself with his followers in an occult language. In short, he was threatening the livelihood of his colleagues in the profession. Moreover, most of what we read of Lacan was not originally intended as a publication but was formed from notes from seminars to aid his followers and students.

我开始讲授文本时会回顾索绪尔和结构主义者，因为镜像阶段源自他们的语言立场。关于这一背景材料，需要强调的一点是，他们坚持认为语言不是人们学会使用的工具，如锤子或钳子。相反，语言是一个系统。在这里，我使用游戏的类比。对于拉康来说，语言类似于棒球或板球等运动。你不会认为拥有球棒和球并熟悉规则就能玩游戏。语言也是如此：词汇和语法规则不足以说一门外语。为什么？你需要和其他人一起玩游戏，也就是说，与那些懂这门语言的人交谈，因为词汇和规则不是以明显的方式合乎逻辑或指称的。我们说“门”；法国人说“la porte”。然而，我们说 portal 表示门口：无法提供任何合乎逻辑的解释。但如果一个法国人指着一扇门说它是“porte”，我们会以为他不知所措，他可能确实如此，可怜的家伙。索绪尔表明，语言不是简单地用词代替事物。斯威夫特讽刺了这种观点，他在《格列佛游记》中让一位投影仪建议我们随身携带物品，而不是说话，这样可以避免误解。这个想法的荒谬性清楚地表明，语言不是简单的指称方式，而是复杂得多。在这里，拉康关于两个孩子走进火车站的轶事也表明了同样的观点。

I begin teaching the texts by going back to Saussure and the Structuralists because the mirror stage derives from their linguistic position. The point to stress about this background material is their insistence that language is not a tool that one learns to wield like a hammer or pliers. Rather, it is a system. Here I use the analogy of a game. Language for Lacan is similar to sports like baseball or cricket. You would not assume that having the bat and ball and being familiar with the rules would enable you to play the game. So too with language: vocabulary and grammar rules are not sufficient to speak a foreign language. Why? You need to play the game with others, that is, to speak with those who know the language, because the vocabulary and rules are not logical or referential in an obvious way. We say “the door”; the French say “la porte.” Yet we say portal for doorway: no logical explanation can be offered. But if a Frenchman pointed to a door and called it a “porte,” we would think he was at sea, which he probably is, poor devil. Saussure demonstrated that language is not a simple substitution of word for thing. Swift satirized this view by having one of his projectors in Gulliver’s Travels recommend that instead of speaking we should carry objects with us and point to them, thereby avoiding misunderstanding. The absurdity of this idea makes clear that language is not referential in a simple fashion but much more complex. Here Lacan’s anecdote of the two children coming into the railway station makes the same point.

一旦将语言理解为具有一致但任意规则的系统或游戏，我们就可以进入拉康心理学。语言确实超越自身指向所谓的“现实”，但拉康坚持认为这是一种永远无法实现的理想，也就是说，我们这些拥有相同文化的人相信一种“现实”，而在另一种文化中，这种“现实”可能被视为纯粹的幻想。无论如何，从语言到“现实”，再到所指，需要解释，而这种解释往往是隐藏的或隐晦的，就像“太阳升起”这个表达一样，从字面上来说，它指的是用语言来说，就是“地球在转动”。镜像阶段涉及自我或自我意识，从我们将自己的形象与名字联系起来的那一刻起，自我就沉浸在语言系统中。从那一刻起，我们就成为了话语系统的一部分，就像写作或说话一样，这个系统允许一些个人表达，但只能在明确的参数和规则内，即语法、拼写、发音、礼貌惯例等。拉康断言，将自我设想为语言之外的本能或驱动力是一种误导，适得其反。语言从一开始就存在，是精神分析师唯一可用的手段——必须明确的是，拉康不是哲学家，而是实践精神分析师。

Once language is understood as a system or game with consistent but arbitrary rules, we can proceed to Lacanian psychology. Language does refer beyond itself to what is called “reality,” but Lacan insists this is an ideal that is never realized, that is, we who share a culture believe in a “reality” that in another culture may be seen as sheer fantasy. In any event, the move from language to “reality,” to the signified, requires interpretation which is often buried or tacit, as in the expression “the sun rises,” referring, in literal terms, to “the earth turns.” The mirror stage involves the self or ego being immersed in a linguistic system from the moment we associate our image with our given name. From that point onward we are part of a discursive system which, like writing or speaking, permits some individual expression but only within clear parameters and rules, that is, grammar, spelling, pronunciation, conventions of politeness, etc. Lacan asserts that to conceive of the ego in terms of instincts or drives apart from language is misleading and counterproductive. Language is always there from the outset and is the only means at the disposal of the psychoanalyst—and it is important to make clear that Lacan was not a philosopher but a practicing psychoanalyst.

最后，我发现许多学生都反对他们的身份完全存在于语言中的观点。许多人认为他们在学会说话之前就有一个核心自我，他们可能是对的。就我们的目的而言，这场辩论留给心理学家和精神分析学家更有成效，因为他们对这个问题仍然有激烈的争论。无论自我是全部还是部分是话语的产物，拉康都向我们表明，我们需要意识到它对我们的影响。本章中的任何一部电影都相当有力地证明了这一点：这些电影中任何忽视语言或语言心理影响的角色都会付出沉重的代价。现在我直接转向拉康的伟大创新，即无意识作为语言，这个概念可能也会遇到一些阻力。同样，我会采取回避行动：即使语言只是次要的，它也是我们接触无意识的唯一手段，因此精神分析学家遵循类似于文学评论家的程序，聆听或阅读以了解说话者或作家试图传达的内容。不同之处在于，精神分析学家寻找的是隐藏或掩饰的东西，而文学评论家则专注于文本。但他们都使用相同的手段来达到不同的目的，因为我们所有人都在某种程度上像文学人物一样，参与到话语中，而话语的背景需要解释。所有电影都表明，将语言视为指称性的透明玻璃，而不是呈现“现实”的不透明玻璃，只有通过解码才能瞥见，这种做法是危险的。从女王将“人民的公主”斥为转瞬即逝的新闻，到国王认为他的口吃只是机械的，我们看到了解释的必要性，不仅对我们理解电影有好处，而且对涉及其中的主体也有好处，以便解决他们的问题。拉康的精神分析方法涉及文学和文学之外的背景下的解释行为。

Finally, I find that many students are resistant to the notion that their identity is wholly present in language. Many believe that they have a core ego prior to learning to speak, and they may be right. For our purposes, this debate is more fruitfully left to psychologists and psychoanalysts for whom this matter is still hotly contested. Whether the ego is wholly or in part a product of discourse, Lacan shows us that we need to be aware of its effect upon us. Any of the films in this chapter demonstrate that point quite emphatically: any character in these films who neglects language or the psychological ramifications of language pays a heavy price. Now I turn directly to Lacan’s great innovation, the unconscious as language, a notion that also will probably meet with some resistance. Again, I would take evasive action: even if language is only secondary, it is the only means we have of access to the unconscious, so the psychoanalyst follows a procedure like that of a literary critic, listening or reading in order to understand what the speaker or writer is trying to communicate. The difference is that the psychoanalyst looks for what is hidden or masked and the literary critic remains with the text. But they both use the same means toward a different end, because all of us are to some extent like literary characters involved in discourse, a context that requires interpretation. What all of the films show is the danger of proceeding as if language were referential, clear glass, rather than opaque glass presenting a “reality” glimpsed only by way of decoding. From the Queen’s dismissal of “the people’s princess” as ephemeral journalism to the King’s assumption that his speech impediment is merely mechanical, we see the necessity of interpretation, not only for us if we are to understand the movies, but also for the subjects involved in order to resolve their problems. Lacan’s psychoanalytic method pertains to the act of interpretation in both a literary and extra-literary context.

第五章 后马克思主义，弗里德里克·詹姆逊

Chapter Five: Post-Marxism, Fredric Jameson

我开始讲授后马克思主义时，首先要解决什么是辩证法的问题，这是大多数学生不理解的一个术语。我的解释是与磁学的类比是恰当的，因为在黑格尔和马克思的时代，电磁学是一个主要的科学问题。两个相互矛盾的极点建立了一个与单独存在的场不同的场，结果是没有一极占主导地位。相反，它们的相互作用产生了与从它们各自的特性中预测的完全不同的东西。当然，磁学和辩证法的区别在于后者是稳定的，而前者，对黑格尔来说，可能会改变，对马克思来说，必然会改变。黑格尔的辩证法涉及个人自我意识的提升，这种提升不是必要的，而且可能在任何阶段停滞不前。黑格尔通常被归类为唯心论者，辩证法程序旨在上升到他所谓的“绝对精神”。马克思的辩证法是历史本身，从定义上讲，历史是会发生变化的，因此辩证法的不稳定和运动与个人自我意识无关。事实上，马克思断言，物质世界，即历史，首先发生了变化，然后是自我意识。詹姆逊试图将两者结合起来，在马克思的历史辩证法中为个人自我意识保留了一席之地。詹姆逊的创新之处在于，文学的内在形式实际上是自我意识的个人的声音，詹姆逊认为，这种声音被庸俗的马克思主义所忽视或淹没，庸俗的马克思主义只关注任何个人无法控制的更大的历史力量。詹姆逊对单一的自我意识声音感兴趣——重要的是，这种自我意识的声音是个人有意识地表达的，不一定是他或她自己，而是他或她的个人立场。詹姆逊认为，在艺术中刻意表达自己的立场涉及形式和内容的融合；艺术通过这种结合以奇特而奇妙的方式对我们产生影响。

I begin teaching post-Marxism by tackling the problem of what is dialectics, a term most students do not understand. My explanation is by way of an analogy with magnetism, appropriate since in Hegel’s and Marx’s time electromagnetism was a major scientific concern. Two contradictory poles set up a field different from either in isolation, and the result is that neither pole predominates. Instead, their interaction produces something quite different than could be predicted from their individual properties. Of course, the difference between magnetism and dialectics is that the latter is stable while the former, for Hegel, may change and for Marx will inevitably change. Hegel’s dialectic involves the rise of individual self-consciousness, an ascent that is not necessary and that may be stalled at any stage. Hegel is usually categorized as an idealist, the dialectical procedure is designed to rise to what he called “Absolute Spirit.” Marx’s dialectic is history itself that is subject by definition to change, and so the destabilization and movement of the dialectic is not a matter of individual self-consciousness. In fact, Marx asserted that the material world, that is history, changed first and that self-consciousness then followed. Jameson tries to combine both, preserving a place for individual self-consciousness within Marx’s historical dialectic. The inner form of literature, Jameson’s innovation, is really the voice of the self-conscious individual which Jameson believes has been ignored or drowned out by vulgar Marxism that focuses only upon larger historical forces beyond the control of any single person. Jameson’s interest in the single self-conscious voice—and it is important that it is the self-conscious voice in that the person knowingly or consciously is putting forward, not necessarily him or herself, but his or her personal position. This deliberate putting forward of one’s own position in the arts involves for Jameson the intermingling of form and content; art works on us in strange and wondrous ways by virtue of this combination.

任何一部电影都会提供生动的例子：我个人最喜欢的电影《邮差》用音乐为马里奥和聂鲁达的关系提供了一个正式的结构，因此在最后，当聂鲁达想象马里奥的死亡时，手风琴的音乐主题又以“轻音”钢琴的形式回归。通过这种方式，电影告诉我们，马里奥终于加入了聂鲁达，不仅仅是作为朋友或崭露头角的诗人，而且是一位诗歌对历史产生影响的艺术家。在这里，我们可以看到为什么詹姆逊作为后马克思主义者特别关注艺术，并坚持认为艺术的声音必须包含在历史辩证法中。最好的艺术家有独到的见解，并以优美而清晰的形式呈现给我们。因此，对于詹姆逊来说，忽视创新思想的来源，即成功传达给他人的思想，对马克思主义者来说是一个巨大的损失，因为它是未来新可能性的源泉，是可以影响积极变化的因素，是历史的力量。最后，由于许多人认为马克思主义等同于革命，因此学生们需要确信，并非所有马克思主义者都认为变革必须涉及暴力动乱。相反，像詹姆逊这样的后马克思主义者暗示，艺术往往提供了一种和平合法的颠覆和改变的手段权威。但请注意，正统派或詹姆逊所说的“庸俗马克思主义者”会将这种想法视为“逃避”，马克思称之为“资产阶级宣传”，即中产阶级权威似乎容忍颠覆性艺术家，但实际上并没有改变其基本原则。这就是为什么詹姆逊认为他的马克思主义版本必须融入黑格尔自我意识的个人声音，而这本质上是艺术家的声音。

Any of the films will provide vivid examples: “Il Postino,” my personal favorite, uses music to give a formal structure to the Mario–Neruda relationship so that at the end, when Neruda imagines Mario’s death, the musical motif of the accordion returns now as a “soft-pedaled” piano. In this way, the movie speaks to us, saying that Mario has finally joined Neruda, not just as a friend or a budding poet, but as an artist whose poetry has an effect on history. And here we can see why Jameson as a post-Marxist is particularly interested in art and insistent that its voice must be included within the historical dialectic. Artists at their best have original ideas and present them in forms that speak beautifully and articulately to us. So, for Jameson, to ignore that source of innovative ideas, ideas that are successfully communicated to others, is a great loss to the Marxist, for it is a source of new possibilities for the future, a factor that could influence positive change, a force of history. Finally, since many assume that Marxism is synonymous with revolution, the students need to be assured that not all Marxists believe that change must involve violent upheavals. On the contrary, a post-Marxist like Jameson implies that art often provides a means of peacefully and lawfully subverting and changing the establishment. But be warned, orthodox or what Jameson calls “vulgar Marxists” will regard this idea as a “cop-out,” what Marx called “bourgeois propaganda,” that is, the middle-class establishment seeming to tolerate the subversive artist but not really changing its fundamental principles. That is why Jameson argues that his version of Marxism must incorporate Hegel’s self-conscious individual voice, which is quintessentially that of the artist.

第六章 后女性主义：埃莱娜·西苏

Chapter Six: Post-feminism: Hélène Cixous

在将西苏的作品作为女权主义或女性理论的一个例子来教学时，我强调两个概念：过程而不是产品；批判性与创造性的融合。

In teaching Cixous’s work as an instance of feminism or feminine theory, I emphasize two concepts: process rather than product; and the intermingling of the critical and the creative.

西苏的女权主义版本是，所有男性主导的叙事、包罗万象的思想，都应受到解构主义的影响。但是，尽管德里达提倡出于任何目的进行解构主义，但西苏却暗示，目标应该是具体的、明确的，阐明一件艺术作品和/或推进一项事业，无论是社会、政治还是哲学。因此，性欲，即先于爱情但不一定转向爱情的性冲动，是这一过程的推动力。你必须非常关心这件事，并应该把这种关心公开化。是的，像德里达一样，你可以玩弄语言，应该玩弄自己，不要太严肃，但这个问题是严肃的。你总是知道西苏关心什么；德里达往往很难说。有时对德里达来说，这似乎是哲学游戏的纯粹乐趣。你可以用你的时间做更糟糕的事情，但西苏很少允许自己有这种奢侈。作为一名女权主义者，她不断面对不公正，不公正不仅针对女性，还针对少数群体、个人和创新思想。这种过程理论的结果是临时结论、暂时目标，它们服务于特定目的，但会因新项目、新需求和历史而受到修改。从这个意义上说，这个过程是永无止境的；掌握是一种幻觉。但在此过程中，艺术作品得到了启发，问题得到了解决，或者在一段时间内得到了补救。像一位优秀的老年病学家一样，西苏斯理论家无法改变衰老过程，即历史，但可以通过关注特别令人烦恼的问题来缓解和延长这一过程。德里达将他感兴趣的问题“问题化”，而西苏斯则关注对他人的关心所引起的问题，这是力比多的终极力量。

Cixous’s version of feminism is that all male master narratives, all-encompassing ideas, are subject to deconstruction. But while Derrida advocates deconstruction for any purpose, Cixous implies that the goal should be concrete and specific, the elucidation of a work of art and/or the advancement of a cause, be it social, political, or philosophical. For this reason libido, the sex drive that precedes but may not necessarily move on to love, is the moving force of this process. You must care deeply about the matter and should make that care overt. Yes, like Derrida, you may play with the language and should be playful about yourself, not take yourself too seriously, but the issue is serious. You always know what Cixous cares about; often with Derrida it is hard to tell. Sometimes for Derrida it seems to be the sheer joy of philosophical play. There are worse things you can do with your time, but Cixous seldom allows herself this luxury. As a feminist, she is constantly confronted with injustice, not only to women but also to minorities, individuals, and innovative ideas. The results of such a process theory are provisional conclusions, momentary goals that serve a specific purpose but are subject to revision by fresh projects, new needs, by history. In that sense, the process is unending; mastery is an illusion. But along the way, works of art are illuminated and problems are resolved or, for a time, remedied. Like a good gerontologist, the Cixousian theorist cannot alter the aging process, that is, history, but can soothe and lengthen the path by focusing upon particularly vexing problems. While Derrida “problematizes” issues of interest to him, Cixous attends to issues evoked by care for others, the ultimate force of libido.

创造性和批判性交织在一起对学生来说很困难，因为它们通常是截然分开的。所以他们认为一部作品要么以创造性为主，要么兼具批判性和理论性，这是一种难以放弃的古老二元论。但当然，西苏同时兼具这两种特质。她也没有试图以某种不正当的方式将她的理论强加给无辜的文学读者，反之亦然，偷偷地将她的文学作品当作理论来呈现。相反，她的思维方式渗透到了她作品的各个方面，就像我们大多数人一样，尽管我们中很少有人能像她一样在两方面都做得好。我鼓励学生像阅读任何故事或戏剧一样阅读她的创作作品，并进行相应的分析。然后，也只有这样，他们才能将其与她的批判性写作联系起来。但对于西苏来说，这两者是相关的——这是她的作品和德里达作品之间的另一个区别——因为她的所有作品都像文学一样，都是目的论的，也就是说，有特定的最终目标，因此适合解释学。

The intermingling of creative and critical is difficult for students since they are usually clearly separated. So they assume that a work is either predominantly creative or critical and theoretical, an old binarism that is difficult to give up. But, of course, Cixous is both at once. Nor is she trying in some underhanded way to foist her theories on innocent readers of her literature or vice versa, surreptitiously presenting her literature as theory. Rather, her way of thinking pervades all aspects of her work, as it does for most of us, although few of us can do either as well as she does both. I encourage the students to read her creative work as they would any story or play, and analyze it accordingly. Then and only then should they relate it to her critical writing. But the two are related for Cixous—and here is another difference between her work and that of Derrida—because all of her writings are, like literature, teleological, that is, with specific end goals and thus amenable to the hermeneutics of interpretation.

最后，我鼓励学生们不要将临时结论视为简单的修补或创可贴，因为他们从经常光顾计算机商店的经历中清楚地知道，在我们这个瞬息万变的时代，完整的系统一旦进入市场就过了保质期。我用“Rosenstrasse”来说明所有这些观点。最重要的是，结论显然是临时的。这些犹太男人最终会怎样还有待商榷，但这丝毫不会影响妇女的成就。她们保留了一些与丈夫在一起的日子，这无疑会受到珍惜，只要有一个男人能从死亡集中营逃脱，这一切都是值得的。此外，这个临时目标最明显的动机是对丈夫的爱，这一点非常明显，以至于士兵们没有向她们开枪。而妇女的成就完全是女性的成就，因为她们没有采取任何攻击性行为，事实上，这就是她们赢得至少暂时胜利的方式和原因。如果他们的胜利仅仅在于推迟了不可避免的事情发生，将他们的士兵被带走的时间推迟了几天或几周，那么任何人不妨问问大屠杀的幸存者，为了少经历一天地狱般的生活是否值得努力。

Finally, I encourage the students not to dismiss provisional conclusions as a mere patching up or band-aid, for they well know from their frequent visits to computer stores that complete systems are, in our fast-changing times, past their shelf life as soon as they hit the market. I use “Rosenstrasse” to illustrate all of these points. Most importantly, the conclusion is decidedly provisional. What will happen to these Jewish men ultimately is open to question, but that does not take away one iota from the accomplishment of the women. They have preserved some days of togetherness between themselves and their husbands that will undoubtedly be cherished, and if only one man escapes from the death camps, that alone will make it all worthwhile. Moreover, this provisional goal is most clearly motivated by love of their husbands, something so obvious that it alone must have been so apparent as to stop the soldiers from firing their guns at them. And the accomplishment of the women is completely feminine in that not a single aggressive act was committed by them, and, in fact, that is how and why they won at least a temporary victory. And if their victory is only in having postponed the inevitable, put off for a few days or weeks the time when their men will be taken away, let anyone ask a survivor of the Holocaust if a day less of that hell was worth struggling to attain.

结论

Conclusion

课程结束时，学生们经常会问我的理论是什么，他们说的是我的主理论。我让他们看我的书，书目列在下面，因为我的观点不是主理论。但我最后警告他们，理论是鸦片，即相信全面的概念本身优于折衷的混合物。通常世界事件提供了例证。例如，在写这篇文章的时候，西方和世界许多其他地区正陷入金融危机。提出的唯一解决方案是经济理论。重要的是要理解，看似简单的口袋理论是一种理论，即国家就像个人一样，在口袋空空的时候不能继续支付钱。人民和国家之间的类比非常抽象，在我看来，这是一种非常值得怀疑的理论。这一理论正在引起大规模抗议全世界都出现了这种情况，因为有些人，其中许多人接近问题的根源，即使不是原因，也只受到了轻微的影响，而那些失去家园和工作的人与问题的发生几乎没有任何关系。如果我们要避免世界大灾变，就必须用一种更关心责任伦理而不是资产负债表的替代理论来修改这一理论。这一进程目前正在布鲁塞尔的欧洲政客中展开。对我来说，只有一件事是肯定的。没有一种理论能够或将会占上风。不要忽视折衷主义。它可能会拯救我们的世界。

At the end of the class, students often ask what is my theory, by which they mean, my master theory. I send them to my book, listed in the Bibliography below, for my position, not, I believe, a master theory. But I conclude by warning them about the opiate of theory, the belief that a comprehensive notion is in itself superior to an eclectic mixture. Usually world events provide illustrations. For example, at the time of writing the West and many other parts of the world are gripped by a financial crisis. The sole solution posed is an economic theory. And it is important to understand that the seemingly simple pocket theory is a theory, namely that countries like individuals cannot continue to pay out money when their pockets are empty. The analogy between people and countries is highly abstract and, in my view, a very questionable theory. This theory is causing mass protests throughout the world because some people, many close to the source, if not the cause, of the problem are only slightly affected while those losing homes and jobs had little if anything to do with causing the problem. If we are to avoid a world cataclysm, this theory will have to be modified by an alternative one more concerned with the ethics of responsibility than balance sheets. That process is presently being fought out in Brussels among European politicians. Only one thing is certain to me. No single theory can or will prevail. Do not dismiss eclecticism. It may save our world.

参考书目

BIBLIOGRAPHY

前言

Preface

拉尔夫·科恩（Ralph Cohen）。 “文学理论作为一种体裁”，载《Centrum》（1975 年春季）。

Ralph Cohen. “Literary Theory as a Genre,” in Centrum (Spring, 1975).

诺思洛普·弗莱。《批评的剖析》，普林斯顿：普林斯顿大学出版社，1957 年。

Northrop Frye. Anatomy of Criticism, Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1957.

雷内·韦勒克和奥斯汀·沃伦。《文学理论》，纽约：Harcourt Brace and Co.，1949 年。

Rene Wellek and Austin Warren. Theory of Literature, New York: Harcourt Brace and Co., 1949.

第一章

Chapter One

雅克·德里达。《人文科学话语中的结构、符号和游戏》，《结构主义之争》，理查德·麦克西和尤金尼奥·多纳托编，马里兰州巴尔的摩：约翰霍普金斯大学出版社，1970 年。

Jacques Derrida. “Structure, Sign, and Play in the Discourse of the Human Sciences,” in The Structuralist Controversy, Richard Macksey and Eugenio Donato (eds), Baltimore, Maryland: The Johns Hopkins University Press, 1970.

— 《论文字学》，马里兰州巴尔的摩：约翰霍普金斯大学出版社，1998 年（1967 年首次以法语出版，书名为《论文字学》）。

—Of Grammatology, Baltimore, Maryland: The Johns Hopkins University Press, 1998 (first published in French in 1967 as De la Grammatologie).

— 《哲学的边缘》，艾伦·巴斯译，芝加哥：芝加哥大学出版社，1982 年（1972 年首次以法语出版，书名为《哲学的边缘》）。

——“白色神话；哲学文本中的隐喻”，载《新文学史》第6卷（1974年秋）。

—“White Mythology; Metaphor in the Text of Philosophy,” in New Literary History, 6 (Autumn, 1974).
